item.title: Should Residents Be Expected to Work Without PPE?
item.description: Estimated read time: 18min. This should go without saying, but the following opinions are mine and mine alone. Source: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html as of April 10, 2020 at 11:50AM. The Pandemic Situation I‚Äôve been thinking about this deeply for the past couple of days. As the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases worldwide continues to climb above 1.6 million, the number of deaths is more than 100 times the number of deaths from the 2003 SARS outbreak and more than 4 times the number of deaths from the 2009 H1N1 swine flu pandemic.

item.title: COVID-19 and Climate Change
item.description: Estimated reading time: 10 minutes‚Ä¶ but there are pretty pictures! I attended an online webinar the other day organized by the Canadian Association of Physicians for the Environment (CAPE). The session was titled ‚ÄúCOVID-19 and climate change - Where do we go from here?‚Äù and consisted of a panel of speakers, including physicians and other board members of the organization. I was interested because I had heard something about carbon emissions dropping ever since people have been staying home and the economy had been slowing down.

item.title: 7 Tips for Starting Med School
item.description: …#7 changed my LIFE!! Lol Starting med school has been simultaneously the most exciting and the most overwhelming time of my life. It‚Äôs only been a month, and I already feel a lot of the responsibilities of ‚Äúbeing a doctor‚Äù. Like Shakespeare wrote in Twelfth Night, it‚Äôs kind of been thrust upon me, all of a sudden. Starting the Problem Based Learning (PBL) model here at Mac was a little analogous to being thrown into the deep end, where at least before there were familiar creatures like marked exams and projects‚Äîhave now been replaced by a void of vague tutorial objectives, optional anatomy labs, and ‚Äúprofessional competency‚Äù.
